prop.head.headtext: Thorburn, Law of Confidential Business Information

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Claims for Breach of Confidential Business Information

para.paratext: In order to succeed in an action for breach of confidence, the plaintiff must establish that:
confidential information was communicated as a result of a relationship of confidence;[1] and
the information was misused by the party receiving it.[2]

In Exchange-A-Blade Ltd. v. Ber-Zel Building Materials Ltd.,[3] the plaintiff sued for wrongs it believed were committed by the defendants in the nature of conspiracy, breach of noncompetition agreements, and the wrongful solicitation of the plaintiff's business opportunities. It sued two different groups. The Radkie defendants were from the Wetaskiwin area and were involved in business that distributed the plaintiff's products in that northern/central Alberta area. The Storteboom defendants were involved in a distributorship of the plaintiff's products in the southern Alberta area. The Storteboom defendants applied for particulars, although they had already delivered their statement of defence. They submitted that the claim as pled was too sweeping and nonspecific and that in order to know what the claim was against them, and in particular to know what records to produce, and how to prepare for questioning, they wanted to know more particulars.[4]

The nature of the claim was, in part, one of conspiracy and breach of confidentiality obligations. Rules 13.6(3) and 13.7 set out various kinds of claims that require specifics, although the list in rule 13.6(3) is inclusive, not exclusive. Breach of confidence and conspiracy are not included. As a rule, conspiracy claims involve a complaint that the defendants have secretly been working together. It is inherent in the nature of the claim that the plaintiff likely does not know all of the specifics. The plaintiff does not know what conversations or written communications were had, and when. A claim for breach of confidence also usually has the same hobble. With that in mind, the plaintiff could not provide too many specifics at the outset. The Master concluded that there is some level of “fishing” that is necessary to fully prosecute claims of this kind.[5]

The Master observed that if the approach of requiring details early in the process was followed too strictly, few people could properly advance a claim of conspiracy or breach of confidence. Plaintiffs can often show little more than the consequences of what appears to have been a wrong committed in secret by the defendants. The Master noted that it must be remembered that the pleadings are intended to define the issues and particulars may be required to meet that end—to allow the defendants to know what case they have to meet and to put brackets around the limits of the lawsuit.[6]

Paragraph 20 of the Statement of Claim was a pleading that both defendant groups passed on confidential information to a specific competitor and that Radkie became primarily responsible for the competitor's client contact in northern and central Alberta, and Mr. and Mrs. Radkie became the contact in southern Alberta, and each commenced harming the plaintiff. Paragraph 23 alleged that both groups provided confidential information, had been involved in activities contrary to their obligations, solicited the plaintiff's customers with the intention of selling the competitor's product or services, taken actions on behalf of the competitor which may impair the plaintiff's relations with its customers, and directed others to conduct competitive acts, with some particularity. Paragraphs 24 and 25 provided some general descriptions about contacting specific customers of the plaintiff, redirecting the plaintiff's customers to the competitor. Both Radkie and Storteboom were said to have seized corporate opportunities belonging to the plaintiff. It is clear to the Master that the claim related specifically to a particular competitor of the plaintiff, specific agreements that the defendants were said to be bound by, and customer accounts claimed to have been taken—when the defendants were the plaintiff's representatives in Alberta until their agreements ended.[7]

The Master observed that it was clear that the plaintiff was not aware of many details. However, it was aware of the loss of business throughout the province to a specific competitor, and the apparent communications between at least the Radkies and the competitor, and it knew that they had a business relationship as to the warehouse operations. There was more than mere suspicion at this stage. With this background, the Master concluded that there was enough to support the allegations as a viable claim, and there was enough for the defendants to know what the claim brought against them is about. They knew the identity of whom they were said to be supporting (the competitor) they knew who they were said to have conspired with (each group with the other) and they knew the general nature of the loss claimed.[8]

The nature of the claim involved dealing with the possibility of some secrecy in which the defendants were engaged. The plaintiff was likely to be working to some extent in the dark at the outset. That was in the Master's view probably why the Alberta Rules of Court do not specifically require particulars of a claim for conspiracy or breach of confidence. The Master concluded that as long as the plaintiff has some objective basis for the general nature of the claims, it is normal pleading practice to assert the sorts of related allegations that commonly accompany claims of breach of confidentiality and non-competition agreements, so as to avoid objections in questioning if a particular detail is not alleged. Those had been sufficiently particularized for the defendants to know what the claim against them was, and to place brackets on their obligations and extent of disclosure. Accordingly, the Master did not require the plaintiff to provide any more particulars.[9]

In PR Construction Ltd. v. Colony Management Inc.,[10] an application was brought by Lacroix and his company to strike portions of Colony's Counterclaim alleging misconduct on the part of Lacroix. Colony had subcontracted the steel erection portion of a construction project to PR. Colony employed Lacroix, a professional engineer, as project manager. Colony terminated Lacroix's employment effective December 31, 2013. Lacroix was hired by PR in January 2014. In the spring of 2014, the relationship between Colony and PR deteriorated and the work stopped. Colony refused to pay amounts invoiced by PR on the project. PR sued and Colony counterclaimed against PR, its principal, Lacroix and his company. In Colony's Counterclaim, it alleged that it relied on confidential information to carry on business and Lacroix had certain obligations as senior project manager and engineer. Colony claimed that Lacroix did various unauthorized acts while employed by Colony which accrued to the benefit of PR, including processing unauthorized change orders. Once employed by PR, Lacroix continued to do work for PR relating to the contract with Colony. Colony alleged that Lacroix accessed confidential information including privileged legal advice provided to Colony in relation to the contractual issues between the parties and deleted confidential information at the time of his departure from Colony.[11]

The Applicants submitted that Colony was essentially trying to sidetrack PR's claim for payment by advancing scandalous and improper allegations against Lacroix. The Applicants applied to strike the portion of the Counterclaim alleging breach of confidence and copyright on the basis that there was no pleading of a factual basis that would support a cause of action. Rather, the applicant's alleged that the Counterclaim simply set out the generic framework for those claims. The Applicants submitted that Colony had not pled material facts to show that: the information conveyed was confidential, it was conveyed in confidence, and it was misused by Lacroix to the detriment of Colony. Colony alleged in the Counterclaim that Lacroix provided confidential information to PR, including privileged legal advice relating to the winter work, deleted confidential information in Colony's records, and unlawfully converted certain confidential information for the use of Lacroix, PR and its principal.[12]

The application judge observed that the essence of Colony's claim was that Lacroix occupied a key senior and trusted position in Colony, exercised considerable autonomy, was privy to confidential information, and had certain duties in relation to that confidential information which he breached. Colony's broader allegation was that Lacroix, while employed by Colony, acted for the benefit of PR and to the detriment of Colony, through the unauthorized sharing of information and commission of certain acts, and that he continued to act to Colony's detriment after leaving Colony and taking employment with PR, for example through improper solicitation of Colony's employees and business contacts in competition with Colony. The facts pleaded must be presumed to be true for the purposes of the motion to strike. The application judge concluded that the Applicants had not established that there was no reasonable prospect that the claim would succeed.[13]

In No Limits Sportswear Inc. v. 0912139 B.C. Ltd.,[14] the plaintiffs claimed that the defendants misused confidential information provided to them by the plaintiff No Limits. The confidential information related to the plaintiffs' business plans in relation to a brand of men's underwear known as SAXX underwear. The plaintiffs alleged that the defendants misused the confidential information to develop and eventually launch in the following year a competing brand of men's underwear, the brand “MyPakage”. The plaintiffs pleaded that as a result of the defendants' alleged misconduct, the plaintiffs suffered a loss of opportunity and a reduction of their market share and market position, and they sought compensatory damages in this regard. The plaintiffs submitted that their damages should be calculated based on the theory that all sales and gifts by the defendants of MyPakage underwear, to date and for some years into the future, should be treated as a loss of sales of SAXX product by the plaintiffs. The plaintiffs projected damages of approximately $23 million into 2018.[15]

The defendants submit that the third element of a breach of confidence claim, namely misuse of confidential information, also requires that the unauthorized use of the information be to the detriment of the information-provider in order to complete the cause of action. Thus they argue, if the information-provider has suffered no damages, there is no valid claim for breach of confidence. The trial judge observed that the defendants overstate the clarity of the law on this issue, stating as follows:

The facts in Lac Minerals were that the defendant did make unauthorized use of the information to the detriment of the plaintiff. The judgment of La Forest J. in Lac Minerals commented on this as part of the analysis of the third element above, but it is unclear whether he was referring to the remedy rather than the cause of action because he also held that any use other than a permitted use was a breach of duty: see 635–642.
In Cadbury, the issue before the Court concerned the proper remedies for breach of confidence. The fact of breach of confidence was not questioned.
The Court in Cadbury at para. 54 declined to rule definitively on the question of whether detriment to the information-provider is a necessary element of the cause of action for breach of confidence.

In Minera, the BC Court of Appeal noted that the law is unsettled on whether detriment is a necessary element of an action in breach of confidence: see para. 85. However, in that case a detriment was proven.

In Seaway Marine Services Ltd. v. Weiwaikum General Partner Ltd., 2014 BCSC 2102 (B.C. S.C.), Thompson J. dealt with a claim for breach of confidence and held that “the proposition that detriment is an essential element of the cause of action is not entirely free of doubt” at para. 94.

Nevertheless, the judgment in Cadbury does suggest that general damages for breach of confidence cannot be awarded where the party suing has elected to claim that the breach of confidence caused financial loss but has failed to prove a financial loss. This appears to be the reasoning of Binnie J. at paras. 52–54:

[52] La Forest J. said in Lac Minerals that if the plaintiff is able to establish that the defendant made an unauthorized use of the information to the detriment of the party communicating it, the cause of action is complete (at pp. 635–36 and 657; see also ICAM Technologies Corp. v. EBCO Industries Ltd. (1991), 36 C.P.R. (3d) 504 (B.C.S.C.), affirmed (1993), 52 C.P.R. (3d) 61 (B.C.C.A.), per Toy J.A., at pp. 63–64; Ontex Resources Ltd. v. Metalore Resources Ltd. (1993), 13 O.R. (3d) 229 (C.A.); 655 Developments Ltd. v. Chester Dawe Ltd. (1992), 42 C.P.R. (3d) 500 (Nfld. S.C.).

[53] The issue of detriment arises in this case because the trial judge made a specific finding that the respondents had not suffered financial loss, yet she proceeded to find liability and award damages “in the interest of fairness”. While La Forest J. in Lac Minerals considered detriment to be an essential element of the breach of confidence action (Sopinka J. did not express a view on this point in his discussion of the applicable principles), it is clear that La Forest J. regarded detriment as a broad concept, large enough for example to include the emotional or psychological distress that would result from the disclosure of intimate information (see, e.g., Argyll (Duchess) v. Argyll (Duke), [1967] Ch. 302. In the Spycatcher case, supra, Lord Keith of Kinkel observed, at p. 256, that in some circumstances the disclosure itself might be sufficient without more to constitute detriment:

So I would think it a sufficient detriment to the confider that information given in confidence is to be disclosed to persons whom he would prefer not to know of it, even though the disclosure would not be harmful to him in any positive way.

[54] The concept of detriment need not be explored on this occasion because, as the Court of Appeal correctly emphasized, the parties had agreed prior to trial that any evidence regarding losses allegedly suffered by the plaintiff would be deferred to a post-trial reference. This arrangement obviated the need for the respondents to lead evidence of detriment at the liability trial. In the end, however, having elected the remedy of financial compensation, the respondents will obviously have to demonstrate at the reference the nature and extent of any detriment suffered to establish the basis for a monetary award. [Emphasis added.][16]

The trial judge concluded that since the goal of the remedy for breach of confidence is to restore the plaintiff to the position it would have been but for the breach, that in a case where the only remedy claimed is compensation for the plaintiff's losses, failure to prove any losses would mean failure to prove entitlement to a remedy.[17]

There need not be an express or implied contract in order for an action for breach of confidence to succeed.[18] An action for breach of confidence is often brought in circumstances in which there is a pre-existing non-contractual relationship or a contemplated contractual relationship.[19] The courts have often taken the position that when information of a commercial or industrial nature is communicated in a business-like manner “with some common object in mind”, the recipient carries a heavy burden if he or she wishes to deny that there is an obligation of confidence.[20]

Receipt of confidential information in circumstances of confidence establishes a duty on the confidee not to use that information for any purpose other than that for which it was conveyed. Therefore, the confidee has the obligation to demonstrate that his or her use of it was not a prohibited use.

In LAC Minerals Ltd. v. International Corona Resources Ltd.,[21] the court interpreted “misuse” of information as the use of information to the confidor's detriment. More specifically, the established principle commonly known as the “springboard principle” was set out as follows in Seager v. Copydex Ltd.:

“… a person who has obtained information in confidence is not allowed to use it as a springboard for activities detrimental to the person who made the confidential communication, and springboard it remains even when all the features have been published or can be ascertained by actual inspection by any member of the public”.[22]
The courts will look to what each of the parties knew and understood at the time confidential information was transferred.[23]
